speaker: therapist
text: Hello Alex. Welcome. This marks our fifth session, and as we discussed last time, we’ll be focusing on integration and conclusion today. How has the past week been, holding the idea of the void as a reservoir of love?

speaker: client
text: Hi Dr. Lee. It’s been... different. Saying ‘This is my love’ when I feel that hollow ache... it didn’t make the pain disappear, but it changed my posture towards it. I’m not fighting it. I’m... carrying it. It feels like a weight I’m learning the shape of, instead of a trap I’m trying to escape.

speaker: therapist
text: ‘Learning the shape of the weight’—that is the work of integration. You’re no longer at war with your own grief. I’d like to take some time today to look back at the path we’ve walked over these sessions. Would that be okay?

speaker: client
text: Yes, I think that would be good.

speaker: therapist
text: In our first session, you came in feeling stuck, pressured, and burdened by guilt over ‘not doing enough.’ The pain was raw and overwhelming. Do you remember what your primary hope was then?

speaker: client
text: I said I wanted to learn how to remember Jordan without it tearing me apart every time. To breathe again.

speaker: therapist
text: And in our second session, we did that deep dive. We found ‘The Prosecutor’ in the cereal aisle, and you had the crucial insight that guilt was an ‘anchor’—a terrible one—against the chaotic sadness of pure loss.

speaker: client
text: That feels like a lifetime ago. The Prosecutor hasn’t gone away, but it’s lost its power. I can name it now. ‘Ah, there’s that old familiar charge.’ It feels more like a habit than a truth.

speaker: therapist
text: Exactly. We externalized it. Then, in our third session, you brought in Jordan’s own voice—the birthday card. That was a turning point. You introduced the most important witness. How has that perspective stayed with you?

speaker: client
text: I keep the card on my nightstand. Sometimes I just touch it. It’s my tangible piece of the ‘truth of us.’ When I feel disconnected, it reminds me that our story was real and complex and loving. It grounds me in what was, instead of the nightmare story my grief was spinning.

speaker: therapist
text: Beautiful. Then, in our last session, we went to perhaps the deepest layer: moving past the narratives to the raw feeling itself. The void. And you named it not as emptiness, but as a ‘vast, unused reservoir of love.’ How has that reframe settled in?

speaker: client
text: It’s been the most liberating and the hardest. Liberating because it’s honest. Hard because it means accepting that this love, this weight, is now a permanent part of my anatomy. I’m not waiting for it to be over. I’m learning to live with it as a part of me. It’s the love I have for him. It has nowhere else to live but with me.

speaker: therapist
text: You are describing what we call ‘integration.’ The loss becomes woven into the fabric of your life, not as a gaping hole, but as a defining pattern. The goal of grief therapy is not a ‘return to normal’ or ‘closure,’ but the development of a new relationship with the loss—and with yourself. Do you feel you’ve begun to build that new relationship?

speaker: client
text: I have. I’m in relationship with my grief now, instead of being assaulted by it. I talk to it. ‘Okay, love, you’re heavy today. I’ll carry you.’ It sounds strange, but it’s peaceful. And I’m in a different relationship with Jordan. He’s not just a source of pain; he’s the reason for this reservoir. I can remember his laugh now, and sometimes it brings a smile before the tears. They can coexist.

speaker: therapist
text: The smile and the tears coexisting—that is the hallmark of integrated grief. You have done phenomenally brave work, Alex. You faced The Prosecutor, you sought out counter-evidence, you sat in the terrifying void and discovered it was made of love. You have built a toolkit: naming cognitive distortions, seeking narrative truth, grounding, and compassionate reframing. Where do you feel you are now in relation to your initial hope—to remember Jordan without being torn apart?

speaker: client
text: I’m there. Not all the time. Some days the waves still knock me down. But I know how to breathe when I’m underwater now. I know it will pass and I’ll find the surface again. I can remember him, and the pain is there, but it’s wrapped in love, not wrapped in guilt. It’s a clean pain. And clean pain, as hard as it is, doesn’t destroy you. It changes you.

speaker: therapist
text: ‘A clean pain.’ That is perfect. Your work has been to clean the wound of the corrosive infection of guilt and self-blame, so it can heal as it needs to. As we conclude our work together, what do you see as the next steps for yourself in carrying this forward?

speaker: client
text: I want to keep a journal. Not every day, but to write to that reservoir. To put some of that love into words, maybe for myself. And I’m considering a support group, like we mentioned once. Not because I’m lost, but because I think I have something to offer now, too. To be in a community that gets it.

speaker: therapist
text: Both are excellent steps. The journal is a way to continue the narrative work, and the support group is about community—giving and receiving. It signifies you are ready to connect your experience to others’. That is a sign of tremendous growth. My door will always be open if future waves feel too complex to navigate alone. But I have every confidence in your capacity to carry this.

speaker: client
text: Thank you, Dr. Lee. You didn’t give me answers. You gave me a lantern so I could see my own path in the dark. I’ll always be grateful for that.

speaker: therapist
text: And I am grateful to have witnessed your journey. You have been a courageous and insightful traveler. Remember, you are not leaving Jordan behind. You are learning how to walk forward with his love integrated into who you are. That is the conclusion of this chapter of therapy, but not of your healing. Go gently, Alex. You have everything you need.

speaker: client
text: I will. Thank you for everything.
